content.question:
Read each question carefully. Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight.

Students will hang rings from the ceiling to demonstrate the trajectory of a projectile. A launcher will send a small ball into the air at a velocity and angle that will allow the ball to pass through all the rings, as shown in the figure. The horizontal position <math alttext="x"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and vertical position <math alttext="y"><mstyle><mrow><mi>y</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> of the ball at different points along the trajectory must be determined so that the rings can be placed at the correct positions.

The students set the launcher for a launch angle of <math alttext="theta equals 40 degrees"><mstyle><mrow><mi>θ</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>40</mn><mi>°</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and measure the range of the projectile in order to determine its launch speed. The following data are collected.

Range

Trial 1
 <math alttext="8.92 meters"><mstyle><mrow><mn>8.92</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>m</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>

Trial 2
 <math alttext="8.96 meters"><mstyle><mrow><mn>8.96</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>m</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>

Trial 3
 <math alttext="9.10 meters"><mstyle><mrow><mn>9.10</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>m</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>

Trial 4
 <math alttext="9.07 meters"><mstyle><mrow><mn>9.07</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>m</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>

Trial 5
 <math alttext="9.16 meters"><mstyle><mrow><mn>9.16</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>m</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>

(a) Derive an equation for the vertical position <math alttext="y"><mstyle><mrow><mi>y</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> of the projectile during its flight. Express your answer in terms of <math alttext="x"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="v sub 0"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="theta"><mstyle><mrow><mi>θ</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, and physical constants, as appropriate.

frqParts.text:
Read each question carefully. Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight.

Students will hang rings from the ceiling to demonstrate the trajectory of a projectile. A launcher will send a small ball into the air at a velocity and angle that will allow the ball to pass through all the rings, as shown in the figure. The horizontal position <math alttext="x"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and vertical position <math alttext="y"><mstyle><mrow><mi>y</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> of the ball at different points along the trajectory must be determined so that the rings can be placed at the correct positions.

The students set the launcher for a launch angle of <math alttext="theta equals 40 degrees"><mstyle><mrow><mi>θ</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>40</mn><mi>°</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and measure the range of the projectile in order to determine its launch speed. The following data are collected.

Range

Trial 1
 <math alttext="8.92 meters"><mstyle><mrow><mn>8.92</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>m</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>

Trial 2
 <math alttext="8.96 meters"><mstyle><mrow><mn>8.96</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>m</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>

Trial 3
 <math alttext="9.10 meters"><mstyle><mrow><mn>9.10</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>m</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>

Trial 4
 <math alttext="9.07 meters"><mstyle><mrow><mn>9.07</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>m</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>

Trial 5
 <math alttext="9.16 meters"><mstyle><mrow><mn>9.16</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>m</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>

(a) Derive an equation for the vertical position <math alttext="y"><mstyle><mrow><mi>y</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> of the projectile during its flight. Express your answer in terms of <math alttext="x"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="v sub 0"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="theta"><mstyle><mrow><mi>θ</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, and physical constants, as appropriate.

(b) Using the data for the range, calculate the launch velocity <math alttext="v sub 0"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> of the projectile.

(c) Using your equation from part <math alttext="a"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, calculate the height of the projectile above the launch point when the projectile has traveled a horizontal distance of <math alttext="5.13 meters"><mstyle><mrow><mn>5.13</mn><mtext>m</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(d) The students use a video camera to measure the position of the projectile at various points in time. From video analysis of the flight of the projectile, the students obtain the following data. The projectile was at the launch point at <math alttext="time equals 0"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.

<math alttext="time, in seconds"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mtext>s</mtext><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="x, in meters"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mtext>m</mtext><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="y, in meters"><mstyle><mrow><mi>y</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mtext>m</mtext><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>

0.000
 0.383
 0.776

0.282
 2.57
 1.81

0.482
 5.51
 2.43

1.015
 9.98
 2.07

1.515
 14.9
 1.13

i. Indicate below which quantities should be graphed to yield a straight line whose slope could be used to calculate a numerical value for the initial speed <math alttext="v sub 0"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> of the projectile.

Vertical axis: Horizontal axis:

Use the remaining rows in the table above, as needed, to record any quantities that you indicated that are not given.

ii. Plot the data points for the quantities indicated in part <math alttext="d, 1"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mtext>d</mtext><mo>)</mo></mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mtext>i</mtext><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> on the graph below. Clearly scale and label all axes including units, if appropriate. Draw a straight line that best represents the data.
iii. Use the straight-line graph to calculate a value for <math alttext="v sub 0"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>.

iv. Using your answer from part <math alttext="c"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mtext>c</mtext><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> as the accepted value, calculate the percent difference for the calculated values of <math alttext="v sub 0"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> from parts <math alttext="c"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mtext>c</mtext><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="d, 3"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mtext>d</mtext><mo>)</mo></mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mtext>iii</mtext><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(e) The launch a second projectile with a smaller launch angle. Is the range of the second projectile greater than, less than, or equal to the range of the original projectile?

Greater than Less than Equal to

Justify your answer.

skill.text: 1.B: Create quantitative graphs with appropriate scales and units, including plotting data.
